Astronomy is the study of the universe beyond Earth's atmosphere. It involves understanding the behavior and properties of celestial objects, including stars, galaxies, planets, and comets. Astronomers use various techniques, such as telescopes and spacecraft, to collect data and observations about these objects. They also use mathematical models and computer simulations to analyze and interpret the data. One of the main goals of astronomy is to understand the origins and evolution of the universe. Astronomers study the life cycles of stars, the formation of galaxies, and the properties of dark matter and dark energy. They also explore the possibility of life beyond Earth, searching for exoplanets and studying the conditions necessary for life to exist. Astronomy has many applications, including improving our understanding of the universe, developing new technologies, and inspiring future generations of scientists and engineers.

Cosmologists explore the origin and fate of the universe, including the Big Bang theory and dark matter. These findings have greatly expanded our understanding of the universe and its many mysteries. Through the study of astronomy, scientists and researchers continue to unravel the secrets of the cosmos, pushing the boundaries of human knowledge and understanding.
